metadata.purpose: Test whether artists with geographic surnames focus on place-based work
metadata.hypothesis: Geographic surname → place-focused art at 45% rate (vs 18% baseline)
metadata.note: Starter sample - expand to 1,000 for publication

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: Leonardo da Vinci

place_focus_analysis.landscape_backgrounds: Nearly all portraits include detailed landscape backgrounds
place_focus_analysis.interpretation: Obsessive attention to landscape detail even in portraits

painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: da Vinci (from Vinci) → landscape backgrounds in nearly every work

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: Vincent van Gogh

place_focus_analysis.interpretation: Deeply connected to specific places (Arles, Auvers-sur-Oise)

painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: van Gogh (from Gogh) → obsessive landscape painter, place-identity strong

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: Claude Monet

place_focus_analysis.notable_obsession: His own garden at Giverny (250+ paintings)
place_focus_analysis.interpretation: Ironically MORE place-focused than many WITH geographic surnames

painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: CONTROL: No geographic surname but extremely place-focused (challenges hypothesis)

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: Rembrandt van Rijn

place_focus_analysis.interpretation: Primarily portrait painter despite geographic surname

painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: COUNTER-EXAMPLE: van Rijn (from Rhine) but NOT landscape focused

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: Caspar David Friedrich

notable_works: Wanderer above the Sea of Fog
place_focus_analysis.interpretation: PURE landscape painter with no geographic surname

painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: CONTROL: No geographic surname, extremely place-focused (challenges hypothesis)

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: El Greco

place_focus_analysis.interpretation: Painted Toledo obsessively despite being Greek, lived in Spain

painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: El Greco (The Greek) → painted Spanish city with Greek light quality

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: Pablo Picasso
painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: Control: No geographic surname, no place focus - as expected

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: Georgia O'Keeffe

place_focus_analysis.irony: Named 'Georgia' but obsessed with New Mexico
place_focus_analysis.interpretation: Place-focused despite wrong place in name

painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: Georgia (state name) → obsessed with different place (New Mexico), but still place-focused

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: Jackson Pollock
painters_with_geographic_surnames.place_reference: Pollock may derive from place names, unclear

place_focus_analysis.interpretation: Abstract work but conceived as American landscape energy

painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: Unclear geographic surname, abstract but 'American landscape' conceptually

painters_with_geographic_surnames.name: J.M.W. Turner

place_focus_analysis.interpretation: PURE landscape painter with no geographic surname

painters_with_geographic_surnames.notes: MAJOR COUNTER-EXAMPLE: Turner (occupation) not place, yet ultimate landscape painter

writers_with_geographic_surnames.name: William Faulkner

place_focus.yoknapatawpha_county: Fictional Mississippi county in nearly all novels
place_focus.interpretation: Invented fictional place, obsessively returned to it

writers_with_geographic_surnames.notes: COUNTER-EXAMPLE: No geographic name, but most place-obsessed American writer

writers_with_geographic_surnames.name: Thomas Hardy

place_focus.wessex: Fictionalized Dorset/Southwest England in all novels

writers_with_geographic_surnames.notes: COUNTER-EXAMPLE: Hardy (character trait) not place, but place-obsessed novelist

writers_with_geographic_surnames.name: Marcel Proust

place_focus.remembrance_of_things_past: Paris and Combray (fictional town) as central characters

writers_with_geographic_surnames.notes: Place-focused (memory of places) without geographic surname

writers_with_geographic_surnames.name: Pearl S. Buck
writers_with_geographic_surnames.place_reference: Buck (male deer) - nature but not place

place_focus.china_setting: Lived in China, wrote The Good Earth and China novels

writers_with_geographic_surnames.notes: Buck (nature) → wrote about rural China (land/earth), weak but present

initial_finding.interpretation: WEAK EFFECT in pilot sample - hypothesis NOT strongly supported
initial_finding.confound: Many landscape painters regardless of surname (Turner, Monet, Friedrich)
initial_finding.revised_hypothesis: Geographic surnames may not predict place-focus as strongly as expected

alternative_pattern_detected.finding: Landscape painting was dominant genre 1600-1900 regardless of surname
alternative_pattern_detected.landscape_as_default: 50-70% of painters focused on landscape in this era
alternative_pattern_detected.hypothesis_revision: Need to control for era and medium. Try writers or contemporary artists.

next_steps_for_full_study.alternative_hypothesis: Test other surname types (nature names, color names, etc.)

preliminary_conclusion.verdict: Pilot suggests WEAK or NULL effect for geographic surnames → place art
preliminary_conclusion.counter_examples_strong: Turner, Monet, Friedrich (no geographic names, massive landscape focus)
preliminary_conclusion.pivot: Maybe geographic FIRST names matter more? (Georgia O'Keeffe)
preliminary_conclusion.or_pivot: Maybe place-focus is medium default, not name-driven
